Article Title: Madison Keys clinches Adelaide title in perfect Australian Open warm-up
Article Text:
Madison Keys (Photo Credit: WTA)

Madison Keys warmed up for the year's first Grand Slam, the Australian Open , in style as she defeated fellow American Jessica Pegula in three sets to win the Adelaide International .Keys's second title in Adelaide came in a 6-3, 4-6, 6-1 triumph over the world No. 7."Jess had an amazing week, coming out of the gates in the first week and making the final," said Keys. "I also got off to a good start and I'm looking forward to what's to come this season."It is the ninth WTA title for the world No. 20 Keys who required medical attention for her left knee during the second set. But she persevered, as last year's US Open finalist Pegula forced a decisive third set.Keys regained her composure to secure victory on her first match point, building momentum ahead of her Australian Open opening-round match against compatriot Ann Li."I haven't been back here (Adelaide) since 2022 when I won the title. I feel I should be back every year in Adelaide," Keys said.Pegula, meanwhile, admitted that her opponent was the better player on the day."I had, like, three winners; it was tough. Maddie hits the ball harder than anyone; she played some amazing tennis ," said Pegula. "This was a good week to start the season for me. I'm excited to keep it going (into the Australian Open) in Melbourne ."
Article Summary: Madison Keys beats Jessica Pegula in three sets to win the Adelaide International. Keys beats Pegula 6-3, 4-6, 6-1 to claim her ninth WTA title. Keys will play compatriot Ann Li in the first round of the Australian Open.

Article Title: Gael Monfils makes history as oldest ATP singles champion at 38
Article Text:
Gael Monfils (AP Photo)

At 38 years old, Gael Monfils achieved a historic win at the Auckland Classic on Saturday, becoming the oldest singles champion in ATP Tour history. His victory came just a day before the Australian Open begins in Melbourne.Monfils dominated the final, defeating Belgian qualifier Zizou Bergs in straight sets, 6-3, 6-4. This win surpasses Roger Federer 's record as the oldest ATP Tour champion, which Federer achieved at the Swiss Indoors in 2019.This victory marks Monfils' 13th career title, solidifying his place in tennis history. He is now the oldest player to win an ATP final since the Tour's inception in 1990.After securing the championship point, Monfils celebrated with the crowd, expressing pride in his accomplishment at an age when many players have retired."Age is just a number, but I keep working," he said.Monfils' first ATP Tour title dates back to 2005, showcasing his longevity in the sport."I keep believing that I can play high-quality tennis and I've been showing it this week, so I'm very happy."He spoke about his enduring passion for the game."It was 20 years ago, and I still have the passion to play tennis. I still feel like I strike a very good ball, so hopefully many more to come."Despite the hot conditions in Auckland, Monfils displayed impressive athleticism against Bergs, who was competing in his first ATP final.Bergs struggled to maintain his serve early in both sets and lacked the power to break Monfils' consistent serve and varied groundstrokes.This win propels Monfils 11 spots up the world rankings to 41st. He carries this momentum into the Australian Open, where he will face fellow Frenchman Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard in the first round.
Article Summary: Gael Monfils defeated Zizou Bergs 6-3, 6-4 in the final of the Auckland Classic. He is now the oldest player to win an ATP final since the Tour's inception in 1990. This win surpasses Roger Federer's record as the oldest ATP Tour champion.

Article Title: 'I’ve worked on my footwork to be more aggressive': India No.1 Sumit Nagal all set for Australian Open 2025
Article Text:
Sumit Nagal (PTI Photo)

NEW DELHI: Sumit Nagal is priming for a big match in just the right manner -- on a sun-kissed afternoon, on the very court he is scheduled to play his first-round Australian Open match some 24-hours later -- in Melbourne Park ’s 1573 Arena which has a 3000-strong seating capacity.Nagal, who’ll take on Czech Tomas Machac , the 26seed on Sunday, turned out for practice in a dusty mauve Asics shirt with neon orange branding. The Indian reflected some of that luminous vibe in his shot making, hitting with intent against the world No.47 Zhizhen Zhang, cheered on by a smattering of fans, looking for weekend entertainment.The India No.1, ranked 96 on the Tour, told TOI in an exclusive chat, that he worked hard on his game in the off-season, stepping it up a notch to give his counter-punching play extra zip.“I’m playing well, moving well, I’ve been working a lot on my tennis in the last few weeks, made technical and tactical changes,” Nagal said. “I’ve worked on my footwork -- how you approach the ball, also a little bit of a mindset thing, to be more aggressive, especially on these types of courts. In the last few matches, I’ve started to feel the change. I feel like I'm adapting to it pretty good now.”Nagal, who went down to American Patrick Kypson, ranked outside the top-200, in his first match of the 2025 season, qualified for the main draw in Auckland by putting out Frenchman Adrian Mannarino, once ranked in the top-20, in the final round of the qualifying competition.Against the 24-year-old Machac, Nagal has his work cut out. The gifted Czech, whose penchant to attack the net, is backed by a versatile backhand that sets up the moves for him, is also quick around the court.“He’s a very good player, he’s playing his best tennis right now,” Nagal said. “He likes to play fast tennis, come to the net, these courts suit him. I need to push him physically, make the rallies longer. If I can do that, I see chances.”The 27-year-old has been smart with choice of practice partners this week, going for the aggressive players, the disrupters of rhythm that is so fundamental to his style of play. He hit with Nick Kyrgios on Friday.“It's been a while since I’ve seen him (Kyrgios), we’ve always had a hi-hello sort of friendship, a quick chat, how are you doing, kind of thing,” Nagal said. “We share a couple of common interests, gaming and Indian food. He loves Indian food. We always have something to talk about, either a new game or a new restaurant in the cities we meet in.”That’s the chatter, as Nagal will tell you, content is everything, all that is played between the lines.
Article Summary: Sumit Nagal will play his first-round Australian Open match on Sunday. The India No.1 will take on Czech Tomas Machac in Melbourne. The 27-year-old has been working hard on his game in the off-season. Nagal qualified for the main draw in Auckland by beating Adrian Mannarino.

Article Title: Seeing Jannik Sinner win titles forces me to practice even harder: Carlos Alcaraz
Article Text:
Carlos Alcaraz (AP photo)

Carlos Alcaraz , who can play any shot in tennis, those in the book and then some out of it, even making stuff up on the run, was asked what gives him the greatest satisfaction as a professional athlete -- playing a particular shot or coming through tight matches.The 21-year-old – performer par excellence -- answered with a crackling smile before turning to words.“When you feel like you can’t miss,” the Spaniard said, “you hit great shots, running forehands, dropshots, volley, serve and volley, everything that you want to do, you feel like it's going to be right, that's the most satisfaction I feel on the court.”The four-time major winner craves the magic more than he does match wins, it's how his victories are designed.Alcaraz, the world No.3, who kicks off his Australian Open campaign against Russian Alexander Shevchenko on Monday, is looking for the only major title that has eluded him in his bid for a career Grand Slam.Alcaraz, who went out to German Alexander Zverev in the quarterfinals last year, looking out of depth without his long-time coach Juan Carlos Ferrero, who underwent knee surgery, is hoping to make amends this time with the former No.1 back in his corner.The Spaniard, in the same half of the draw as the No.2 seed Zverev this time, could run into the 10-time Australian Open champion Novak Djokovic in the quarterfinals, and will only meet the world No.1 Jannik Sinner if the two make the final.Alcaraz leads that riveting rivalry – fire and ice, genius and grit -- 6-4, having beaten the Italian three times last year in a season in which the 23-year-old won two major titles at Melbourne Park and later at the US Open.“When I'm playing against Jannik, I have a different mindset,” Alcaraz said. “When you are facing the best player in the world, you have to do something different. When I'm facing him, I know that I have to play my best if I want to win. That’s it. If I have a bad day against Jannik, it’s 99 percent that you're going to lose. That's what is on my mind every time I play him.”Sinner and Alcaraz split the majors between themselves in 2024.“When I see him win titles, see him on top of the ranking, it forces me to practice even harder,” Alcaraz said. “In practice, I'm just thinking about the things that I have to improve to play against him. That is great for me, having him, having such a great rivalry so far, to give the best of me every day.”Alcaraz, who arrived in Melbourne Park this time with not only Ferrero, but also a second coach in Samuel Lopez, has tweaked his serve to get greater rhythm.“One of the big issues I have on the serve is the rhythm. I didn't get good rhythm. With this one I'm going to get a good rhythm just to hit in the right spot every time,” said Alcaraz. “I have to improve my precision, be more precise on the serve. A good rhythm will help.”Last season the Spaniard sent down 265 aces and won 85 percent of the 709 service games he played. That’s the level of precision the 21-year-old is looking to top, it’s down to the nanometre.
Article Summary: Carlos Alcaraz opens his Australian Open campaign against Alexander Shevchenko on Monday. The world No.3 is looking for the only major title that has eluded him in his bid for a career Grand Slam. The 21-year-old has tweaked his serve to get greater rhythm.

Article Title: Novak Djokovic claims 'food poisoning' ahead of 2022 Australian Open
Article Text:
Novak Djokovic. (Photo by Kyodo News via Getty Images)

MELBOURNE: Novak Djokovic 's shocking claim of being poisoned at a Melbourne hotel in January 2022, where he was detained after arriving in Australia without taking the Covid-19 vaccination, came to light on Friday.In a recent interview the 37-year-old Serb said he was served food contaminated with high levels of lead and mercury.Djokovic, who had his visa revoked and was deported from the country, made the sensational claims in an interview to GQ magazine. The Serb said some of the food he received contained lead and mercury."I had some health issues, and I realized that in that hotel in Melbourne, I was fed with some food that poisoned me," the 24-time major winner said. "I had some discoveries when I came back to Serbia. I never told this to anybody publicly, but I had a high level of heavy metal. I had a very high level of lead and mercury."When asked if he had evidence to link the heavy metal blood levels to food served in the hotel, Djokovic said, "The GQ article came out online yesterday (Thursday), I think it's a February issue, so it's coming out in print version. I've done that interview many months ago. I would appreciate not talking more in detail about that, as I would like to focus on the tennis and why I'm here."Djokovic added, "If you want to see what I've said and get more information on that, you can always revert to the article."Djokovic received support from the outspoken Aussie Nick Kyrgios , who said, "I haven't spoken to him (Djokovic), I didn't even know that. We treated him like s#*t, that's for sure."
Article Summary: Novak Djokovic claims he was poisoned at a Melbourne hotel in January 2022. The Serb was detained after arriving in Australia without taking the Covid-19 vaccination. The 37-year-old Serb said he was served food contaminated with high levels of lead.

Article Title: Sinner doping hearing at sports court fixed for April: CAS
Article Text:
Jannik Sinner. (Pic Credit - X)

The Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) has scheduled a hearing on April 16-17 for world number one Jannik Sinner regarding doping allegations, as announced by the Lausanne-based organisation on Friday.Following Sinner's positive tests for clostebol, a prohibited steroid, in March last year, the World Anti-Doping Agency has challenged the International Tennis Integrity Agency's (ITIA) decision to clear him.The hearing will be private, with CAS confirming that no parties requested a public session.The ITIA had previously accepted Sinner's explanation that the substance entered his system via his physiotherapist's use of a spray containing clostebol during treatment and subsequent therapy sessions.Prior to the Australian Open , the 23-year-old champion expressed uncertainty about the timing of the verdict, stating: "I know exactly as much as you guys know. We are in a stage where we don't know many, many things."Facing Chilean Nicolas Jarry in the first round at Melbourne Park, Sinner acknowledged the ongoing impact of the situation: "You think about this, of course. I would lie if I would tell you I forget. It's something what I have with me now already for quite a long time. But it is what it is. I'm here trying to prepare the Grand Slam. Let's see how it goes."Emphasising his cautious approach, Sinner explained: "I've always been very, very careful on every single medicine I take, even what I eat. When the bottle is open, I throw it away, I take a new one. In my mind I know exactly what happened, and that's how I block it (out). I haven't done anything wrong, that's why I'm still here. That's why I'm still playing."
Article Summary: Court of Arbitration for Sport has scheduled a hearing for world number one Jannik Sinner. Sinner tested positive for clostebol, a prohibited steroid, in March last year. World Anti-Doping Agency has challenged the International Tennis Integrity Agency's (ITIA) decision to clear him.

Article Title: Felix Auger-Aliassime beats Tommy Paul to enter Adelaide final
Article Text:
Felix Auger-Aliassime. (Pic Credit - X)

Felix Auger-Aliassime advanced to the Adelaide International final on January 13 after a gruelling victory over Tommy Paul , winning 7-6 (7/3), 3-6, 6-4 in nearly three hours.The Canadian, seeking his sixth title, will compete in his 16th career final against second seed Sebastian Korda , who defeated Miomir Kecmanovic of Serbia 6-4, 7-6 (7/4).Paul missed his chance to enter the top 10 rankings for the first time. The match was error-prone, with over 90 unforced errors. Paul showed resilience by claiming six of seven games in the second set."I'll try and recover now for the final," Auger-Aliassime said. "The match was about physical and mental effort. There were a lot of ups and downs."It was not the best level from either of us, but sometimes matches are like that, you have to find a way through."In the women's draw, top-seeded Jessica Pegula secured a 7-6 (7/4), 6-3 victory against Yulia Putintseva. She will face fellow American Madison Keys in Saturday's final.The two Americans, who have split their previous encounters, are making history as the first US women to reach this stage in Adelaide. Pegula returns to her first final since the US Open in September.Despite Putintseva's previous day's lengthy match, Pegula acknowledged the challenge. "I was on my toes, I knew she would try and break up the rhythm."I tried to play my game, I knew she would be tricky; I got a bit lucky in the tiebreaker."Keys, defending her 2022 title, progressed after Liudmila Samsonova retired at 5-7, 7-5, 3-0. Samsonova withdrew due to right knee issues."I'm excited to be in another final here," Keys said. "I was really happy to stay in the match. She played unbelievable at the start."It's not how you want to win (through retirement) but I'm glad I was able to stick around and tough it out."
Article Summary: Felix Auger-Aliassime beats Tommy Paul 7-6 (7/3), 3-6, 6-4 in nearly three hours. Canadian will play Sebastian Korda in his 16th career final. Top-seeded Jessica Pegula beats Yulia Putintseva to reach women's final. Pegula will face fellow American Madison Keys.

Article Title: Bhambri-Olivetti pair exits ASB Classic with semi-final defeat
Article Text:
Albano Olivetti and Yuki Bhambri. (Pic Credit - X)

NEW DELHI: Yuki Bhambri from India and his French partner Albano Olivetti lost their semi-final match at the ASB Classic in Auckland , despite a promising beginning.The unseeded Bhambri-Olivetti duo initially held control, but succumbed to the tournament's top seeds Nikola Mektic and Michael Venus , who secured a 3-6, 6-1, 5-10 victory in the ATP 250 event's semi-final contest.For their performance in the hard court competition, Bhambri and Olivetti each earned 90 points and shared $10150 in prize money.The collaboration proved beneficial for India's second-ranked player Bhambri, who had previously partnered with Venus, helping him prepare effectively for the upcoming Australian Open .
Article Summary: Yuki Bhambri and Albano Olivetti lose semi-final match at ASB Classic in Auckland. Top seeds Nikola Mektic and Michael Venus win 3-6, 6-1, 5-10 in ATP 250 event. India's second-ranked player had previously partnered with Venus.

Article Title: Defending champion Jannik Sinner all set for Australian Open amid doping clouds
Article Text:
Jannik Sinner. (Pic Credit - X)

The skies are blue and the sun is unapologetically brazen, not uncommon in the Antipodes this time of the year. Melbourne Park , the sprawling grounds of the Happy Slam, overlooks the Yarra, gliding gently alongside a shimmering carpet.The Australian Open , starting Sunday, is held far from the ructions of a world in a twirl, but even thousands of aeronautical miles isn’t quite far enough for tennis, struggling to move forward from issues of the past year. Ostensibly, a pair of gold standard 23-year-olds, World No. 1 Jannik Sinner and five-time major winner Iga Swiatek , returned positive tests that rocked the core of the game.Sinner, the Australian Open’s defending champion tested positive for clostebol last March. An independent panel, which was presented the case by the International Tennis Integrity Agency, ruled there was ‘no fault or negligence’ on the part of the Italian.The verdict that Sinner bore no fault didn’t sit well with the World Anti-Doping Agency , who in the era of XXL entourages, harps on independent thinking, especially with all that athletes put in their system. Not even a billionth of a gram.WADA has appealed to the Court of Arbitration for Sport and the Italian faces a potential ban of up to two years. The hearing could be slated for February after the conclusion of the first major of the year, but there could be appeals at a higher port, the Swiss Tribunal.Swiatek, the four-time Roland Garros champion, tested positive for trimetazidine in August. The sleep medication she was taking was contaminated.Tennis couldn’t have imagined a darker quandary in the New Year, given that the younger generation of champions had served notice of a new order last season.Sinner and Swiatek, who’ve been careful about everything they put in their body, came out with resilient masks on Media Day on Friday, saying, not much has changed for them.“I’ve done the same thing,” Sinner said. “Before I was very, very careful with every single medicine I took, even what I eat. When the bottle is open, I throw it away, I take a new one.”Swiatek, the four-time Roland Garros champion, who is playing down under with a new coach Belgian Wim Fissette, said, “The contaminated thing was a medication, and medications are treated as tested and clean. The weirdest thing is that the contamination level was ok by Polish pharmaceutical law, but it's not okay in our doping law.”Nick Kyrgios, who has unequivocally taken aim at Sinner, has stopped at nothing – personal or professional.“Having two number ones implicated in doping is abhorrent for our sport,” Kyrgios told reporters in Brisbane. “Right now the state of tennis integrity is widely acknowledged to be terrible – no one seems willing to address it, but it truly is unacceptable. We owe it to the sport to be vocal about it.”The volatile Aussie is backed by Djokovic, going for a historic 25th major title at Melbourne Park, and will open his campaign for a record-equalling 11th Australian Open crown against Indian-American Nishesh Basavareddy.The 37-year-old said, “I'm questioning the way the system works, why certain players are not treated the same as other players.”Interestingly, Sinner, who starts his campaign on Tuesday against Nicolas Jarry, who had tested positive for Lindanrol and Stanozolal and was suspended from the Tour for ten months from January 2020. He was subsequently cleared as the ITF ruled that Jarry ‘bore no significant fault or negligence for his violation’.Sinner, who wore his unruly crown and a blank expression like a model on a catwalk, didn’t give much away.“I haven't done anything wrong, that's why I'm still here,” the world No.1 said. “I don't want to respond to what Nick said or what other players say. The most important part is to have my people around me, they know exactly what happened.”Djokovic’s glittering trophy cabinet should serve as an example for Sinner. The Serb, not really a fan favourite, especially in a cast that included rockstar figures Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal, channelled his energies into winning, Grand Slam after Grand Slam, owning record after record, silencing raging crowds with his inner steel. In doing so he delivered a message that said, love means nothing in tennis, titles are everything.Sinner wouldn’t want to be known only as a two-time major winner, and Swiatek, a five-time champion, the shine and sparkle of silverware could wipe the smudge off their names. Melbourne Park is as good a place as any to get that going again.
Article Summary: World No. 1 Jannik Sinner and five-time major winner Iga Swiatek return positive tests. Sinner, the Australian Open’s defending champion tested positive for clostebol last March. WADA has appealed to the Court of Arbitration for Sport and the Italian faces a potential ban of up to two years.

Article Title: Malaysia Open: Satwik-Chirag crash out
Article Text: Satwiksairaj Rankireddy and Chirag Shetty were defeated in the semifinals of the Malaysia Open BWF Super-1000 in Kuala Lumpur by South Koreans Kim Won Ho and Jae Seung Seo with scores of 21-10, 21-15. The Koreans displayed powerful smashes and strategic gameplay, overcoming the Indians in just 40 minutes.

Article Title: Satwiksairaj Rankireddy and Chirag Shetty exit Malaysia Open in semi-finals
Article Text:
Satwiksairaj Rankireddy and Chirag Shetty (AP Photo)

Indian badminton duo Satwiksairaj Rankireddy and Chirag Shetty 's journey at the Malaysia Super 1000 tournament concluded in the semifinals. They were defeated by the Korean pair of Kim Won Ho and Seo Seung Jae .The seventh-seeded Indian pair, who were finalists in the previous edition, lost 10-21, 15-21 in a 40-minute match.“They played really well, and we could have followed our game plan a bit better. Instead, we played some random strokes, but kudos to them for playing a solid game.”Satwik acknowledged the Koreans' strong performance and admitted their own shortcomings in executing their strategy. He also praised the opponents' solid gameplay.“Today, the pace of the game was very slow compared to the last three days. It’s part of the game. It was a valuable learning experience for us. It is disappointing, but we have a long way to go. Today’s match showed that we can still make it a good fight.”Satwik reflected on the slower pace of the game compared to previous matches. He emphasized the learning experience and the positive takeaway of being competitive despite the loss.The Asian Games champions faced an early setback, trailing 6-11 at the mid-game interval of the first game.They couldn't recover from the deficit, and the Korean pair secured the first game swiftly in 19 minutes.In the second game, Satwik and Chirag displayed improved control and intent. They took an 11-8 lead at the interval.However, they lost momentum, enabling the Korean duo to regain control and win the match comfortably.Kim and Seo have rejoined forces for the 2025 season after achieving success with different partners.Seo won the world title with Kang Min Hyuk in 2023 and previously attained a world No. 7 ranking with Choi Sol Gyu. Kim secured a mixed doubles silver medal with Jeong Na-eun at the Paris Olympics.“They both are playing like a mixed doubles pair now, which is making it tougher.”Satwik humorously observed the playing style of the Korean pair, comparing it to a mixed doubles partnership, which posed a greater challenge.“They are not giving away any easy points, and that’s their best quality. We have to work hard for every point, and that’s exactly what happened today.”He highlighted the Koreans' strength of not conceding easy points, forcing them to work hard for every point.Satwik, whose participation has been limited after the Paris Games due to injuries, suggested that a more assertive approach and mind games might have been beneficial.“We were working really hard, but they were taking easy points whenever they wanted, which kept the pressure off them. In the first game, and even in the second, despite us leading, they maintained their confidence.”Satwik pointed out that despite their efforts, the Koreans' ability to score easy points kept the pressure off them and maintained their confidence.“They could take any point at any time. I think maybe some mind games could have worked here and there. We started a bit calmer, thought the game would come to us, but we could have shown a little more attitude on the court and played with a little more fire.”He reflected on the need for a more aggressive and strategic approach from the start of the match.“I think we started to be a little calmer in the second game. But credit to them, I think we gave away a few easy points from 11-8, but they were also serving quite well.”Chirag acknowledged their calmer approach in the second game but credited the Koreans' serving and their own errors.Satwik and Chirag haven't played extensively since the Olympics.Their next tournament is the India Open Super 750 , commencing on January 14. They will face Malaysia's Wei Chong Man and Kai Wun Tee in the first round.“Really excited. It’s our home tournament and we would really want to go, play well there, and go as deep into the tournament as possible.”Chirag expressed his excitement about playing in their home tournament and their aim to perform well and progress as far as possible.

Article Title: Satwiksairaj Rankireddy-Chirag Shetty storm into Malaysia Open semis
Article Text:
Satwiksairaj Rankireddy and Chirag Shetty (Photo credit: X)

NEW DELHI: India's Satwiksairaj Rankireddy and Chirag Shetty progressed to the semis in the men's doubles event at the Malaysia Open in Kuala Lumpur on Friday.The seventh-seeded pair defeated Malaysian opponents Yew Sin Ong and Ee Yi Teo 26-24, 21-15 in a contest that lasted 49 minutes.In the semifinals, Satwik and Chirag will face South Korea's Won Ho Kim and Seung Jae Seo.Satwik and Chirag were runners-up in the previous edition of the Malaysia Open.The first game was a closely fought contest. Both pairs were evenly matched throughout. At the mid-game interval, the Indian pair held a slim 11-9 lead. They further extended their lead to 18-16.The Malaysian pair then rallied, scoring three consecutive points to tie the game at 19-19. They even briefly took a 20-19 lead.Despite the pressure, Satwik and Chirag remained composed. They saved four consecutive game points. The Indian pair ultimately won the first game 26-24.In the second game, the Malaysian duo started strongly. They held the lead for a significant portion of the game, leading 11-8 at the interval.Satwik and Chirag mounted a remarkable comeback after the interval. They dominated the latter half of the second game.The Indian pair won 13 of the next 17 points, securing their victory and a place in the semifinals.

Article Title: Malaysia Open: Satwiksairaj Rankireddy-Chirag Shetty in QF, other Indians exit
Article Text:
Satwiksairaj Rankireddy and Chirag Shetty (PTI Photo)

Satwiksairaj Rankireddy and Chirag Shetty eased into the quarterfinals while the rest of the Indian squad exited in the second round of the Malaysia Open BWF Super-1000 tournament in Kuala Lumpur on Thursday.Satwik-Chirag defeated Malaysia's Nur Mohd Azriyn Ayub and Tan Wee Kiong 21-15, 21-15 in the second round. In men's singles HS Prannoy saved two match before failing in the third attempt to lose a closely-contested tie against seventh seed Li Shi Feng of China 8-21, 21-15, 21-23.Treesa Jolly and Gayatri Gopichand suffered a similar loss against Chinese pair of Jia Yi Fan and Shu Xian Zhang 21-15, 18-21, 19-21. The girls were leading 17-14 in the second after winning the first game, before the Chinese made a spirited comeback.Mixed doubles pairs of Satish Karunakaran-Aadhya Variyath and Dhruv Kapila-Tanisha Crasto suffered straight game losses. While Satish-Aadhya lost to Goh Soon Huat-Lai Shevon Jemie of Malaysia 10-21, 17-21, Dhruv-Tanisha went down to China's Cheng XingChang Chi 13-21, 20-22.In the last match of the day, China's Han Yue drubbed Malvika Bansod 21-18, 21-11. Satwik-Chirag, who were at their fluent best on Thursday, will face Ong Yew Sin and Ee Yi Teo of Malaysia on Friday. In the 10 matches they played so far, the Indians won five and Malaysian won four with one of them being a walk over. In the last couple of years the Indians dominated the Malaysians.
